channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Black light experiment shows how quickly a virus like Covid-19 can spread at a restaurant
item.description: A viral video from Japan aims to show how easily germs and viruses can spread in restaurants when just one person is infected.

item.title: Trump's rebuke of Fauci encapsulates rejection of science in virus fight
item.description: President Donald Trump's repudiation of Dr. Anthony Fauci has long been probable. Once the trusted doctor warned of the human cost of Trump's push to quickly reopen the country, it became inevitable.

item.title: Fox News hosts target Dr. Anthony Fauci
item.description: After Dr. Anthony Fauci's Senate testimony, where he said the US doesn't have complete control over the coronavirus pandemic, Fox News hosts criticized him. CNN's Jim Acosta reports.

item.title: Brazil records more than 11,000 coronavirus cases in a single day
The UK's four countries take a divided approach to coronavirus crisis
Biologist says to avoid these places to protect against Covid-19
item.description: University of Massachusetts Dartmouth Biology Professor Erin Bromage tells CNN's John Berman which environments have an increased risk of spreading coronavirus.

item.title: US China tensions didn't begin with the coronavirus. They've been building for years
item.description: Relations between the United States and China have sunk to new lows in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, with both sides hoping to make political gains by blaming the other for the severity of the crisis.

item.title: Expect more cases of strange coronavirus syndrome in kids, doctors warn
item.description: Parents, hospitals and clinics should expect to see more cases of a mystifying condition that seems to be affecting children after a bout with Covid-19, doctors said Wednesday.

item.title: Trump privately questions whether deaths are being overcounted
item.description: Questions about the US coronavirus death count have taken hold inside the White House, officials familiar with the matter say, as President Donald Trump and his aides discuss whether figures used by administration to determine mortality rates and death projections are reliable indicators for plotting a path forward.

item.title: Videos show skydivers spiraling in sky before crashing
item.description: Eyewitnesses in Florida captured two skydivers spinning in the sky before they crashed into a tree and landed in front of a home, according to police and firefighters in Titusville.

item.title: What happened to Elon Musk?
item.description: Elon Musk truly entered the public consciousness just over a decade ago, when Tesla was a quirky upstart putting batteries in the chassis of a little Lotus sports car. Musk grew it into an electric powerhouse, building cars that he promised would one day drive themselves, with doors that swung upward much like the time machine from Back to the Future.

item.title: Ousted US vaccine chief will warn Congress of potential for 'darkest winter in modern history'
Typhoon Vongfong rapidly intensifies as it nears the Philippines
item.description: Typhoon Vongfong is rapidly intensifying -- and the Philippines is in its path.

item.title: Newly released incident reports detail US Navy's 'UFO' encounters
item.description: Newly released "hazard reports" detailing encounters between US Navy aircraft and "unidentified aerial phenomena" reveal new details about incidents, which were thrust into the spotlight when the Pentagon officially declassified and released videos of three encounters late last month.

item.title: One church, so many deaths: Pastor says 44 parishioners killed by Covid-19 reveal a troubling truth
European Union suggests phased return to tourism
item.description: The European Union is suggesting a phased return for tourism on the continent for summer holidays, but warns the public would be traveling at their own risk. CNN's Frederick Pleitgen reports.

item.title: Why thousands are willing to be intentionally exposed to Covid-19
item.description: Abie Rohrig had just turned 18 when he told his mom he would be donating a kidney to save a stranger's life. Her answer: No you're not. He did it anyway -- the organ went to a man about his age -- and his mom was so inspired she went and donated a kidney herself.

item.title: Goldman Sachs issues warning about US unemployment
item.description: The unemployment rate in the United States will peak at 25%, rivaling the worst period of the Great Depression, Goldman Sachs warned on Wednesday.

item.title: Doctor tells how to spot Covid-related syndrome in children
item.description: The CDC is warning doctors to look out a mysterious illness in children that could be linked to the coronavirus. CNN's Brianna Keilar speaks to a doctor about the symptoms and how to spot any red flags.

item.title: Woman traveling by foot gives birth, then walks another 100 miles with newborn
item.description: A pregnant woman traveling through India by foot interrupted her journey to give birth and then kept walking for another 160 kilometers (99 miles) with her newborn baby.

item.title: Five surfers die after huge layer of sea foam hampers rescue
item.description: Five surfers who knew the sea "like the back of their hand" have died after a huge layer of foam in the water hampered efforts to rescue them.

item.title: Hear 911 call McMichael made days before Ahmaud Arbery's shooting
item.description: Less than two weeks before the February 23 shooting that left Ahmaud Arbery dead, a suspect arrested in the case had a confrontation with an unidentified African-American man who had entered a neighboring house under construction, according to an attorney for the owner of that house.

item.title: Fox News dumps coronavirus coverage for anti-Obama conspiracy theory
item.description: A version of this article first appeared in the "Reliable Sources" newsletter. You can sign up for free right here.

item.title: Spike in Covid-19 cases in South Korea stokes homophobia
item.description: South Korea, once deemed a success handling the Covid-19 virus, has seen a renewed outbreak emerged in its LGBTQ clubs in the process of reopening. CNN's Paula Hancocks talks to mayor of Seoul on the difficulty of contact tracing.

item.title: US Senate may move soon on Uyghur human rights bill
item.description: The Senate may move as soon as this week to advance a bill to sanction Chinese government officials responsible for forced labor camps in Xinjiang, where up to two million ethnic Muslims have been forcibly detained, a source familiar with the matter told CNN on Wednesday, in the latest congressional move to strengthen the US stance toward China.

item.title: Covid-19 infects intestines, kidneys and other organs, studies find
item.description: The new coronavirus can infect organs throughout the body, including lungs, throat, heart, liver, brain, kidneys and the intestines, researchers reported Wednesday.

item.title: Man refusing to wear mask breaks arm of store employee
item.description: Two men were arrested for felony battery after starting a fight with employees at a Los Angeles Target store over wearing masks inside the store.

item.title: Cats can infect other cats with coronavirus, researchers find
item.description: Cats can infect other cats with the novel coronavirus, but they may not show any symptoms, according to a study published Wednesday.

item.title: White House clarifies there is no talk of altering Election Day after Kushner remarks
2020 has been a tourism catastrophe. These places have been hit hardest
Maurice Fayne, 'Love & Hip Hop: Atlanta' star, arrested for fraud, federal officials say
item.description: Maurice Fayne, who stars in VH1's "Love & Hip Hop: Atlanta," has been arrested and charged with federal bank fraud after misusing funds from a Paycheck Protection Program ("PPP") loan, federal officials said Wednesday.

item.title: Which airlines are flying where, and why?
Rapper's attempt to donate $200,000 to No Kid Hungry rejected
item.description: Tekashi 6ix9ine looks to be doing well financially since his release from prison and apparently wants to share the wealth.

item.title: How expensive will air travel be after the Covid-19 crisis?
item.description: When the state of Florida began enacting stay-at-home measures and closing beaches in mid-March, in response to the threat of Covid-19, Miami-based real estate agent and artist Nadia Bouzid was in the middle of painting a mural inside a new hotel in Cancun, Mexico.

item.title: Diners at this reopening restaurant can get social with dressed up mannequins
item.description: When a three Michelin-star restaurant in Virginia opens its doors back up from the Covid-19 pandemic, reservations will be made for mannequins.

item.title: Germany is finding a unique way back to nightlife
item.description: Germany's cultural institutions are making a comeback, but the way people visit museums and enjoy nightlife has been changed by the Covid-19 pandemic. Business owners have adopted strict hygiene and social distancing guidelines in a bid to fend off the virus. CNN's Fred Pleitgen reports.

item.title: Photographer known for mass nude shots takes his art online
item.description: American artist Spencer Tunick is best known for bringing hundreds -- and sometimes thousands -- of participants together to pose for striking mass nude photographs.

item.title: How the world's most dangerous bird got its unique feathers
item.description: It's been called the world's most dangerous bird. Its long dagger-like middle toes, in fact, were responsible for the death of a man in Florida last year.

item.title: Lingerie is changing. Here's why
item.description: From Vivienne Westwood's Victorian corsetry to Calvin Klein's bias-cut slips, lingerie has always had a place on the runway.

item.title: Adam Sandler's daughter crashes interview
item.description: Comedian and actor Adam Sandler's interview on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" included a special appearance by his daughter, who shared a minor grooming accident that happened to her father.

item.title: Frodo Baggins is now forever part of the US Supreme Court's historical record
item.description: Frodo Baggins is now forever part of the Supreme Court's historical record.

item.title: 'I have a lot of regrets': Tennis champion opens up about her crippling shyness
item.description: Two grand slam titles and a rapid rise to the top of world tennis was a head-spinning ascent for Naomi Osaka.

item.title: Ousted US vaccine chief will warn Congress of potential for 'darkest winter in modern history'
item.description: • Trump and right-wing media distract from bad virus news with alternate reality

item.title: Trump criticizes Fauci advice: 'It's not an acceptable answer'
item.description: President Donald Trump says infectious disease expert Dr. Anthony Fauci wants to "play all sides of the equation" when it comes to reopening schools.

item.title: India plans to bring home 30,000 residents in a week
Pastor says 44 parishioners killed by Covid-19 reveal a troubling truth
item.description: • Doctors tackling Covid-19 are seeing odd and frightening syndromes

item.title: Finally, the Supreme Court can tell Trump he's not above the law
item.description: No president is above the law -- and there were powerful arguments made to support that view in Tuesday's Supreme Court proceeding.

item.title: Melissa Etheridge's son, Beckett Cypher, dies at 21
item.description: Beckett Cypher, the son of Melissa Etheridge and her former partner Julie Cypher, has died, a representative for the singer told CNN. He was 21.

item.title: Suspect in Arbery shooting had earlier confrontation, neighbor says
item.description: Less than two weeks before the February 23 shooting that left Ahmaud Arbery dead, a suspect arrested in the case had a confrontation with an unidentified African American man who had entered a neighboring house under construction, according to an attorney for the owner of that house.
